messageBody:
What about using the mail API, or perhaps some Jabber message API?
It's server-side stuff, which tends to be straightforward to write
tests for. At the end you can still plug the output into a GUI to see
the results of the application. Some folks may be already familiar
with these APIs, but you can turn that into an opportunity to make the
point that the kind of tests you want to write would involve the
content that is sent *via* the APIs, not the adherence to the
standard.

Something like, "whenever x is true, a message should be sent to lists
including Y, with message contents z". Using a mail API, and making
assertions about the mail objects created (without sending them
through an actual mail server) would drive home the point that you
want to test the message *creation* unit, and not necessarily the
actual round-trip of sending the mail and receiving it. Once you've
written your tests, you can the fire up the full application and see
it go in a real enough way (assuming you run a little mailserver
locally for this).

This can be a powerful demonstration of how you can develop code to
APIs using unit tests, even before the implementation is ready. I've
written a good chuck of code to in-house APIs that were not ready or
had major bugs.

Lastly, an illuminating question may be this: What aspects of Unit
Testing do you want to drive home with this example? I'm guessing
your presentation already has these points, and you want your
courseware to reveal them in a pretty obvious way. Here's some
guesses and some ideas for 'tasks' based on above:

Unit tests make development easier.

The initial 'task' of getting the emails/messages sent through the
server is faster because the tests run faster than the email server.
If you're using Jabber, claim that the Jabber API you're using is only
defined, not implemented. Heck, that might even be true at the
moment!

Unit tests make for easier refactoring.

After the initial 'task' is done, tell the users they need to localize
the content messages, sending them in English and Martian, using a
'translator' that you provide. The initial tests are all still valid
in English, and new ones are added for Martian.

I think you'll want to have more than one iteration in your example.
Unit Tests pay you back one release at a time, and over time, that's
where their value is.

-Kevin


On 5/19/05, Elliotte Harold <elharo@...> wrote:
> I'm developing a course on test driven development and JUnit. This
> course will be taught in a variety of formats and lengths ranging from
> 90-minute seminar to one or two day hands on tutorial to a traditional
> university setting. Obviously how much I can cover and how deep I can go
> will vary depending on format, length, and audience level.
>
> I'm wondering if anyone has any good ideas for examples to use in this
> course? Ideally I'd like something that's simple enough to do in a day,
> but still gives attendees a feeling that they've developed something
> real. I could possibly do something involving the Mandelbrot set or
> cellular automata. However, I'd prefer something a little less
> mathematical if possible.
>
> I'd like it to have a GUI component, but at the same time I'd like that
> to show up fairly late in the application, and for the application to
> still make sense if there's not time to cover testing GUIs.
>
> It should be possible to develop this program on a laptop not connected
> to the Internet. i.e. no databases access, network communications, web
> services, the U.S. tax code, and so forth.
>
> Students will have a wide variety of backgrounds so I want to avoid any
> special knowledge of subjects like XML processing, financial
> derivatives, quantum physics, and so forth. I should be able to cover
> the background necessary to start writing the program in 10 minutes or
> less.
>
> Any ideas?
>
